clinical_summary.presenting_complaints: Patient presented with progressive diminution of vision in right eye for past 8 months. Complaints of glare and halos around lights, especially at night. Difficulty in reading newspaper and recognizing faces at distance. Left eye also has mild symptoms but right eye predominantly affected.
clinical_summary.medical_history: Known case of systemic hypertension for 10 years, controlled on Tab. Amlodipine 5mg OD. No diabetes mellitus. No history of previous ocular surgery or trauma. No family history of glaucoma or retinal diseases.
clinical_summary.preop_examination:
Visual Acuity: Right Eye - 6/36 improving to 6/24 with pinhole; Left Eye - 6/12.

Slit Lamp Examination: Right Eye - Grade 3 nuclear sclerosis with posterior subcapsular component (NS3 PSC2). Left Eye - Grade 2 nuclear sclerosis.

Dilated Fundus Examination: Both eyes - Clear view of retina, optic disc healthy with CDR 0.3:1, macula normal, no diabetic or hypertensive retinopathy.

Intraocular Pressure: Right Eye - 14 mmHg; Left Eye - 15 mmHg (within normal limits).

A-scan Biometry: Right Eye - Axial length 23.45mm, IOL power calculation +21.5D for emmetropia (SRK-T formula).

Corneal Astigmatism: <0.75D (within normal limits, no toric IOL required).

Systemic Evaluation: Blood Sugar Fasting 98 mg/dL, HbA1c 5.6% (non-diabetic), BP 130/82 mmHg (controlled), ECG normal sinus rhythm.
preop_investigations: Slit Lamp Examination: RE NS3 PSC2, LE NS2
A-scan Biometry: IOL Power +21.5D for emmetropia
Dilated Fundus Examination: Retina healthy, no DR/HTR
Pre-operative Blood Tests: CBC, RFT, LFT all within normal limits

diagnosis.provisional_diagnosis: Bilateral Senile Cataract (Immature), Right Eye > Left Eye
diagnosis.final_diagnosis: Post-operative status following uncomplicated right eye phacoemulsification with posterior chamber IOL implantation for senile cataract

procedure.name: Right Eye Phacoemulsification with Posterior Chamber IOL Implantation
procedure.anesthesia: Peribulbar block with 2% lignocaine and 0.5% bupivacaine
procedure.technique: Standard clear corneal phacoemulsification performed under peribulbar anesthesia. Superior 2.8mm clear corneal incision with two side port entries at 2 and 10 o'clock positions. Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis performed. Hydrodissection and hydrodelineation completed. Phacoemulsification using divide-and-conquer technique. Complete cortical aspiration. Foldable hydrophobic acrylic IOL (+21.5D) implanted in capsular bag with good centration. Viscoelastic material removed. Wound sealed with stromal hydration. Subconjunctival antibiotic and steroid injection given.
procedure.intraop_findings: Clear cornea, good pupillary dilatation, Grade 3 nuclear sclerosis as expected. No posterior capsular rent, no vitreous loss, no zonular dialysis. Uncomplicated surgery.
procedure.implant_details: Foldable Hydrophobic Acrylic IOL, Power +21.5D, Batch No: IOL2025-4567, implanted in capsular bag with excellent centration and stability

postop_course.immediate_postop: Patient comfortable post-procedure. Visual acuity perception of light with accurate projection in all quadrants. Intraocular pressure digitally normal. Eye pad and shield applied. Shifted to recovery area. Vitals stable. Light refreshments given.
postop_course.at_discharge: Patient reviewed at 4 hours post-surgery. Visual acuity 6/18 improving to 6/12 with pinhole (significant improvement from pre-op 6/36). Slit lamp examination: clear cornea, well-formed anterior chamber, IOL well-positioned in capsular bag, no inflammation. IOP: 16 mmHg. No complications. Patient comfortable, no pain, no redness. Declared fit for discharge with topical medications.

complications: None. Uncomplicated phacoemulsification surgery with excellent post-operative course.
condition_at_discharge: Stable and comfortable. Visual acuity improved to 6/18 from pre-operative 6/36. No pain, no redness, no discharge. IOP within normal limits. Patient ambulating normally. Vitals stable (BP 128/80 mmHg, Pulse 76/min).

discharge_medications.name: Moxifloxacin 0.5% Eye Drops
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 drop in right eye four times daily (8am, 12pm, 4pm, 8pm)

discharge_medications.name: Prednisolone Acetate 1% Eye Drops
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 drop in right eye - Week 1: 6 times/day; Week 2: 4 times/day; Week 3: 3 times/day; Week 4: 2 times/day; then stop
discharge_medications.purpose: Control post-operative inflammation and prevent posterior capsular opacification

discharge_medications.name: Nepafenac 0.1% Eye Drops (NSAID)
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 drop in right eye three times daily
discharge_medications.purpose: Reduction of pain and inflammation, prevention of cystoid macular edema

discharge_medications.name: Carboxymethylcellulose 0.5% Eye Drops (Lubricant)
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 drop in right eye 4-6 times daily or as needed for dryness
discharge_medications.duration: 4 weeks minimum, continue longer if needed
discharge_medications.purpose: Maintain ocular surface hydration and comfort

schedule: Day 1 post-op (11/10/2025): Morning review for vision assessment and IOP check
Day 7 post-op (17/10/2025): Wound assessment, refraction check
Week 4 post-op (07/11/2025): Final post-operative assessment, glasses prescription if needed
Week 6 post-op (21/11/2025): Consider left eye cataract surgery if patient desires
activity_dos: Instill eye drops at prescribed intervals maintaining sterile technique
Wash hands thoroughly before instilling drops
Wear protective eye shield while sleeping for 1 week
Resume normal diet and oral medications
Can watch television and read with adequate lighting from day 2
activity_donts: Avoid rubbing or pressing the operated eye
Do not allow water to enter the eye for 1 week (sponge bath for face)
Avoid swimming and dusty/smoky environments for 4 weeks
No strenuous exercise, heavy lifting (>5kg), or bending below waist level for 2 weeks
Do not drive until cleared by ophthalmologist (usually after 1 week)
warning_signs: Sudden decrease in vision or complete vision loss
Severe eye pain not relieved by paracetamol
Increasing redness or swelling of the eye
Appearance of floaters, flashes of light, or curtain-like shadow in vision field

future_treatment_plan: Patient counseled regarding left eye cataract surgery which can be planned after 4-6 weeks once right eye completely heals. No other ocular pathology detected. Continue management of systemic hypertension with regular physician follow-up. Annual comprehensive eye examination recommended.
